messages.content: Did the original playstation have a depth buffer?

The original PlayStation did not have a depth buffer.

A depth buffer is a hardware feature that is commonly used in modern graphics processing to improve the performance of rendering 3D scenes with overlapping objects. It works by storing the depth information of each pixel in a buffer, allowing the graphics hardware to quickly determine which objects are in front of others, and therefore which objects should be rendered first.

The original PlayStation, which was released in 1994, did not have a depth buffer as it was not a common feature in graphics hardware at that time. Instead, it used a technique called "z-buffering" to handle depth information. Z-buffering works by storing the depth information of each pixel in a buffer, but it is not as efficient as a depth buffer, and it can cause some visual artifacts in the rendered image.

It is worth noting that the lack of a depth buffer did not have a significant impact on the performance of the original PlayStation, as the graphics hardware of the time was not powerful enough to take full advantage of this feature anyway.
